I want to publish content that I wrote in markdown. I want very basic styling like you see in Obsidian, Notion or other Editors. What is the best way to self-publish the content?
Okay, let's explore the best ways to self-publish your markdown content with basic styling similar to Obsidian or Notion. Here's a breakdown of options, considering ease of use, styling capabilities, and ongoing maintenance:
1. Dedicated Markdown Hosting Platforms (Easiest & Recommended for Most Users)

Hypothes.is: This is arguably the best option for replicating the Obsidian experience. It’s built specifically for collaborative note-taking and reading.
Styling: Offers a robust styling system using CSS. You can customize fonts, colors, headings, lists, and more. It’s designed to be highly adaptable.
Features: Supports syncing across devices, collaborative editing, and exporting to various formats (PDF, HTML, etc.).
Cost: Free for personal use; paid plans for teams.
Ease of Use: Very easy to set up and use.
Notion: While primarily a workspace app, Notion handles markdown beautifully.
Styling: Offers a good level of styling through blocks and formatting options. You can create visually appealing pages.
Features: Excellent for organization, databases, and collaboration.
Cost: Free for personal use; paid plans for teams.
Ease of Use: Relatively easy to learn, especially if you're familiar with other Notion users.
Werkr: Specifically designed for publishing and sharing markdown.
Styling: Offers a simple but effective styling system.
Features: Focuses on creating beautiful, readable documents.
Cost: Free for personal use; paid plans for teams.
Ease of Use: Very straightforward.
2. Static Site Generators (More Technical, Greater Control)

MkDocs: A popular choice for creating documentation websites from markdown.
Styling: Uses CSS for styling. You'll need to learn some CSS basics or find a pre-built theme.
Features: Great for creating structured documentation.
Ease of Use: Requires some technical knowledge (command line, basic HTML/CSS).
Hugo: A very fast static site generator.
Styling: Uses CSS for styling.
Features: Powerful and flexible.
Ease of Use: Steeper learning curve than MkDocs.
3. Simple Hosting with Custom CSS

GitHub Pages: You can host static markdown files directly from a GitHub repository.
Styling: You'll need to add your own CSS to style the pages.
Features: Free hosting.
Ease of Use: Requires some technical knowledge (GitHub, CSS).
Key Considerations & Recommendations:

Styling Complexity: If you want a lot of customization, Hypothes.is or Notion are the easiest choices. If you're comfortable with CSS, GitHub Pages or a static site generator offer more flexibility.
Collaboration: If you need to collaborate with others, Hypothes.is and Notion are excellent.
Maintenance: Static site generators require more maintenance (updates, theme changes).
To help me narrow down the best recommendation for you, could you tell me:

What is the primary purpose of publishing your content? (e.g., personal notes, documentation, a public website)
How important is collaboration?
What is your level of technical comfort (e.g., comfortable with the command line, familiar with CSS)?
I want to publish my Obsidian md files via. github pages. I dont want to do any styling. How?
Okay, let's outline the steps to publish your Obsidian notes via GitHub Pages without any styling. This focuses on getting your content out there simply and effectively.
Here’s a breakdown of the process:
1. Understanding GitHub Pages and Static Sites

GitHub Pages is a service that allows you to host static websites directly from a GitHub repository. “Static” means the content is delivered as-is, without any server-side processing or dynamic elements. This is perfect for your Obsidian notes because you want to present them exactly as they are.
2. Preparing Your Obsidian Vault

Folder Structure: Ensure your Obsidian vault is organized in a way that makes sense for your content. While GitHub Pages doesn’t care about the folder structure within your vault, a logical structure within the vault will make it easier to manage your notes.
File Types: GitHub Pages supports common file types like .md (Markdown), .html, .css, .js, .png, .jpg, .gif, etc. You’re primarily using .md files, so make sure they are properly formatted.
No Styling: Crucially, do not include any CSS or JavaScript files in your vault. GitHub Pages will ignore them. Your goal is a plain, unstyled presentation of your notes.
3. Creating a GitHub Repository

Create a New Repository: Go to GitHub and create a new repository.
Repository Name: Choose a descriptive name for your repository (e.g., my-obsidian-notes).
Public vs. Private: Make the repository public so that GitHub Pages can access it.
Initialize Repository: Don’t initialize it with a README file or a .gitignore file. We’re going to upload your entire vault directly.
4. Uploading Your Obsidian Vault to GitHub

Navigate to Your Repository: Once the repository is created, go to the “code” tab.
Copy the Repository URL: Copy the URL that starts with https://github.com/...
Open Obsidian: In Obsidian, go to File > Link local file.
Paste the URL: Paste the GitHub repository URL into the "Link local file" dialog.
Choose "Link": Select the "Link" option. Obsidian will now copy your entire vault into the GitHub repository. This process can take a little while depending on the size of your vault.
5. Enabling GitHub Pages

Go to Settings: In your GitHub repository, click on the "Settings" tab.
Navigate to Pages: In the left sidebar, click on "Pages".
Select Source: Choose "GitHub Actions" as the source. This is the simplest method for static sites.
Save: Click "Save".
6. Deployment

GitHub Actions will automatically build and deploy your site. You'll see a message in the repository indicating that the deployment is in progress. This can take a few minutes.
Access Your Site: Once the deployment is complete, GitHub will provide a URL for your site. It will look something like https://<your-username>.github.io/<your-repository-name>. This is the URL where your Obsidian notes will be displayed.
Important Notes:

No Custom Domains: This method doesn’t allow you to use a custom domain name. It uses a GitHub-provided subdomain.
Updates: When you update your Obsidian notes, the changes will automatically be reflected on the GitHub Pages site because it’s a static site.
Troubleshooting: If you encounter any issues, check the GitHub Pages documentation for troubleshooting tips: https://docs.github.com/en/pages
